Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Situation2: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Story: I sat at my desk, the clock ticking closer to the start of the national continuing education webinar. As a pharmacist, I knew how important it was to stay updated—missing this session could mean falling behind on the latest treatment protocols, something my patients and my license depended on. But as I opened my email, I noticed a reminder from my mentor: “Remember, always reach out if you have any questions or concerns.” I did have a question, a small one about a term I’d come across in my research. It wasn’t urgent, but I knew my mentor valued open communication and expected me to bring up even minor uncertainties. I hesitated, feeling the pressure from both sides. If I emailed my mentor now, I might miss the start of the webinar or lose focus. If I waited, I’d be going against the spirit of transparency my mentor encouraged. My mind raced, torn between the expectations of being a diligent mentee and a responsible pharmacist, unsure which role to prioritize in this moment.
